Award.AwardTitle: The local and global structure of variational solutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The projects in this proposal address classical questions in geometric analysis related to the existence, structure, and compactness of solutions to particular variational problems. In a previous work with N. Kapouleas, the PI developed a gluing construction to produce new examples of embedded constant mean curvature surfaces with finite topology in Euclidean three space. The PI expects that appropriate modifications to the linear problem will allow her to extend their techniques to produce infinitely many new embedded, constant mean curvature hypersurfaces. As a second project, the PI will consider compactness theory for extrinsic biharmonic maps. For sequences of harmonic maps, energy quantization and regularity theory play a key role in establishing the compactness result. The PI intends to show, using comparable results for the biharmonic setting, that the limiting biharmonic map and the maps arising from dilations at concentration points are connected in the image manifold without necks. Finally, the PI will attempt to combine and extend her study of the structure of complete, embedded minimal surfaces with finite topology and the structure of annular minimal surfaces with boundary to understand the structure of complete minimal surfaces with infinite topology.

Solutions to variational problems are critical points for an energy functional and as such are deeply connected with physical phenomenon. As a particular example, minimal surfaces are critical points for area and on sufficiently small scales are area minimizers, with soap films occurring as natural models. The objects and questions considered in this project can be studied through the lens of partial differential equations, analysis, calculus of variations, and submanifold geometry and are of interest to pure and applied mathematicians as well as many physicists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project included a number of new results related to the existence and regularity of variational solutions.

With Kapouleas, we construct infinitely many new examples of constant mean curvature (CMC) hypersurfaces in dimensions three and higher. The construction is quite general and in higher dimensions provides the first examples of CMC hypersurfaces which possess no symmetry. Indeed, our examples are currently the only examples which are not determined via ODE methods.

With Kleene, we use gluing methods to produce minimal disks, embedded and proper in a subset of Euclidean three space, which possess quadratic curvature blow up. The examples are not new, but the method demonstrates a "proof of concept." We expect that this method can be adapted to provide examples of embedded minimal disks with prescribed curvature blow up on any C^1 curve.

In collaboration with Lamm, we prove the full compactness theory for sequences of approximate biharmonic maps into spherical targets. The approximating functions are in L log L and if the L log L energies do not concentrate then the bubble tree picture is analogous to the picture developed by Parker for harmonic maps to smooth manifolds.

In a second work with Lamm, we refine the regularity results for biharmonic maps into Riemannian manifolds. Using the quantitative stratification ideas of Cheeger-Naber, we demonstrate that every minimizing biharmonic map is in W^{4,p} for p between 1 and 5/4. The L^p bounds are dimension independent and do not require a small energy hypothesis.

 

Finally, in collaboration with five coauthors, in yet unpublished work, we determine Lipschitz regularity for harmonic maps from Riemannian manifolds into compact locally CAT(1) spaces. The Lipschitz constant depends only on the energy of the map, the metric of the manifold, and the distance to the boundary. We also prove a compactness result for uniformly converging minimizers and a removable singularity theorem for conformal harmonic maps. Combining these results, we determine a Sacks-Uhlenbeck type theorem. For any finite energy map from a compact Riemann surface into a Riemannian manifold there exists either a harmonic map homotopic to the original map or a conformal harmonic map from a sphere. This result gives the first existence theory for minimal two-spheres in metric spaces.


Last Modified: 08/02/2017
Modified by: Christine Breiner
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The outcomes of this project included a number of new results related to the existence and regularity of variational solutions. With Kapouleas, we construct infinitely many new examples of constant mean curvature (CMC) hypersurfaces in dimensions three and higher. The construction is quite general and in higher dimensions provides the first examples of CMC hypersurfaces which possess no symmetry. Indeed, our examples are currently the only examples which are not determined via ODE methods. With Kleene, we use gluing methods to produce minimal disks, embedded and proper in a subset of Euclidean three space, which possess quadratic curvature blow up. The examples are not new, but the method demonstrates a "proof of concept." We expect that this method can be adapted to provide examples of embedded minimal disks with prescribed curvature blow up on any C^1 curve. In collaboration with Lamm, we prove the full compactness theory for sequences of approximate biharmonic maps into spherical targets. The approximating functions are in L log L and if the L log L energies do not concentrate then the bubble tree picture is analogous to the picture developed by Parker for harmonic maps to smooth manifolds. In a second work with Lamm, we refine the regularity results for biharmonic maps into Riemannian manifolds. Using the quantitative stratification ideas of Cheeger-Naber, we demonstrate that every minimizing biharmonic map is in W^{4,p} for p between 1 and 5/4. The L^p bounds are dimension independent and do not require a small energy hypothesis. Finally, in collaboration with five coauthors, in yet unpublished work, we determine Lipschitz regularity for harmonic maps from Riemannian manifolds into compact locally CAT(1) spaces. The Lipschitz constant depends only on the energy of the map, the metric of the manifold, and the distance to the boundary. We also prove a compactness result for uniformly converging minimizers and a removable singularity theorem for conformal harmonic maps. Combining these results, we determine a Sacks-Uhlenbeck type theorem. For any finite energy map from a compact Riemann surface into a Riemannian manifold there exists either a harmonic map homotopic to the original map or a conformal harmonic map from a sphere. This result gives the first existence theory for minimal two-spheres in metric spaces. Last Modified: 08/02/2017 Submitted by: Christine Breiner
